description:
Hylobates moloch, commonly known as the Javan gibbon or silvery gibbon, is a species of small ape native to the island of Java in Indonesia. It is a member of the gibbon family (Hylobatidae), which are known for their distinctive long arms and brachiation (swinging from tree to tree) locomotion.

The Javan gibbon is characterized by its silver-grey fur, with a distinctive black cap on its head. Adults typically weigh between 5-9 kg and stand around 50-65 cm tall. They are arboreal and predominantly frugivorous, feeding on a variety of fruits, leaves, and insects.

Hylobates moloch is known for its complex social structure and monogamous mating system. They live in small family groups consisting of a mated pair and their offspring. The species is known for its distinctive loud and complex vocalizations, which are used for communication and territory marking.

Javan gibbons are classified as Endangered on the IUCN Red List due to habitat loss and fragmentation, as well as hunting pressure. Conservation efforts are ongoing to protect the remaining populations of this unique primate species.
